race.name: Gunni Grinder
race.tagline: High-altitude Colorado mountain gravel with 10,000 feet of climbing and thin air at 10,000 ft.

vitals.aid_stations: Miles 40, 80. Water, snacks, mechanical. 40+ miles between stations.

climate.description: Cold starts (35-45°F at 7,700 ft), warming to 60-70°F. Dry season (10-15% rain chance). Intense UV exposure above treeline.
challenges: Altitude: 7,700-10,000 ft elevation—oxygen 25-30% thinner than sea level
Cold morning starts require layering strategy
Faster dehydration and bonking at high altitude

terrain.surface: 80% gravel/dirt mountain roads, 15% doubletrack, 5% paved. Rocky, rugged Colorado gravel with embedded rocks.
features: Technical descents (Razor Creek: loose, steep, rocky)
Base elevation 7,700 ft, maxing near 10,000 ft

biased_opinion.summary: Gunni Grinder is high-altitude mountain gravel done right. This isn't a flat power race—it's a climbing test at thin oxygen. You start at 7,700 ft (already higher than most people live) and max out near 10,000 ft. If you're from low elevation, your FTP will drop 10-15%. Your breathing will be labored. Your bonk will come faster. The Cochetopa Pass Road climb (miles 30-45) is a 15-mile grind that just keeps going—not steep, but relentless at altitude. The high alpine sections (miles 50-70) are exposed, windy, and stunning—above treeline with panoramic Rocky Mountain views. The Razor Creek descent is technical and loose—confidence-testing. Gunnison is a hidden gem: small town, big mountains, zero crowds. The post-race BBQ in the park is low-key awesome—burgers, local beer, live bluegrass. It's not a corporate expo. It's a community celebration.
strengths: Genuine altitude challenge—7,700-10,000 ft elevation tests fitness at thin air
Colorado Rockies scenery—alpine meadows, above-treeline exposure, panoramic views
Legitimate climbing—10,000 ft over 120 miles, sustained mountain climbs
Small-town vibe—Gunnison is friendly, low-key, no crowds
weaknesses: Altitude is brutal—if you're from low elevation, you WILL suffer (15% DNF rate)
Travel logistics—Gunnison airport is small/expensive, Denver is 3.5 hours away
Limited aid—only 2 stations over 120 miles (40+ miles between)
Newer event—5 years old, less established than iconic races
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a flat, fast gravel race, look elsewhere. If you want a legitimate high-altitude mountain suffer fest through the Colorado Rockies—Gunni Grinder delivers. You'll either love the altitude challenge or get wrecked by it. Come acclimated, bring low gears, and pack extra nutrition. The views from 10,000 ft are worth the pain. The BBQ at the finish helps, too.

logistics.nearest_airport: Gunnison-Crested Butte (GUC) — 30 miles, 35-minute drive (small regional airport, limited flights)
logistics.alternate_airports: Denver (DEN) — 200 miles, 3.5-hour drive over mountain passes (more reliable)
logistics.lodging_note: Limited in Gunnison—book 2-3 months ahead. Crested Butte (30 miles) has more options but is pricey ski town. Dispersed BLM camping nearby.
logistics.travel_summary: Travel is a pain. Gunnison airport is small/expensive with limited flights. Denver is 3.5 hours away over mountain passes. Rental car mandatory. Budget travel time.
logistics.food_options: 2 on-course aid stations (miles 40, 80). Post-race: BBQ in downtown park—burgers, local beer, live bluegrass.

course_description.character: High-altitude mountain gravel with sustained climbs and big descents. 10,000 ft elevation gain over 120 miles at 7,700-10,000 ft base. Altitude is the defining challenge—oxygen is 25-30% thinner than sea level. Cochetopa Pass (miles 30-45) is a 15-mile sustained grind. High alpine sections (miles 50-70) max out altitude. Taylor Canyon rollers (miles 85-105) finish with relentless punchy climbs. This is a legitimate mountain challenge, not rolling gravel.

suffering_zones.name: Cochetopa Pass Road Climb
suffering_zones.description: 15 miles of sustained climbing at 8,000+ ft elevation. Not steep, but relentless. Altitude makes every pedal stroke harder. Just keep spinning.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Sustained effort at high altitude. Oxygen is thin. Power is down 10-15%. Relentless—no bailout, just grind it out.

suffering_zones.name: High Alpine Exposure
suffering_zones.description: Above treeline. Exposed to wind. Altitude maxes out (9,500-10,000 ft). No shade, no shelter. Oxygen is thin. Where altitude sickness shows up.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Peak altitude. Breathing is hardest here. Wind exposure. No recovery. Altitude sickness (headache, nausea) common.

suffering_zones.name: Razor Creek Descent
suffering_zones.description: Technical, loose, steep, rocky descent. Demands focus and bike-handling. Crashes happen here. White-knuckle if not confident.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Technical skills test when tired. Loose gravel and rocks. Fast riders gap here; cautious riders lose time or crash.

suffering_zones.name: Taylor Canyon Rollers
suffering_zones.description: Constant punchy climbs when legs are cooked. No recovery. Still above 8,000 ft. The grind never ends.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Relentless rollers when glycogen is depleted. Still at altitude. Mentally and physically exhausting—20 miles that feel like 40.

course_description.signature_challenge: 15 miles of sustained climbing at 8,000+ ft elevation. Not steep, but relentless. Altitude makes every pedal stroke harder. Just keep spinning.

history.origin_story: Steady 300+ riders annually. Newer event (5 years) but growing. $5K purse brings regional competitive field.
notable_moments: 2024: Dry, cold start (38°F), warming to 65°F. ~15% DNF (mostly altitude issues).
2023: Perfect conditions, no rain, temps 40-68°F. ~10% DNF.
2022: Brief afternoon rain at mile 80, otherwise dry.

logistics.explanation: Gunnison-Crested Butte airport is regional with limited flights, forcing most riders into 3.5-hour drives from Denver over mountain passes. Small town means limited lodging that books out months ahead, and backup options are expensive Crested Butte ski lodges 30 miles away. Even elite rider Nick Gould notes this race creates logistics challenges that amplify the difficulty.

length.explanation: Jamesdanielosborne calls it "one of the hardest days they've ever had on a bike. Relentless climbs (including that big one near the end)." 120 miles with 10,000 feet of climbing starting at 7,700 feet altitude. DMC's second-hand report captures the pattern: "climb for 20-30 minutes of rough gravel, descend down rough gravel, go through sand, do it again 3-4 times." Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Plindley experienced "hard packed spots with SHARP rocks" that caused 4 flats in 30 miles, forcing a DNF when plugs ran out. The course is "83% gravel and dirt roads" with "some roads receive little to no maintenance and can change drastically after heavy rains." Riders recommend tire inserts and higher PSI to survive the embedded rocks. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: The route climbs to Los Pinos Pass at 10,500 feet, which bikepacking route descriptions call "the high point" with "high alpine experience." From The Ground Up riders faced a "10+ mile, 2,300ft climb" at Lost Canyon they described as "the longest, toughest gravel road climb of their lives." The math delivers: 10,000 feet of gain over 120 miles. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: Jamesdanielosborne warns "It can also still be very hot in Gunnison this time of the year" for early September. oldandfast noted weather "does seem 7-10 degrees higher from where I live" and did "panic sauna sessions" for heat adaptation before the race. The temperature swings from cold starts to hot afternoons create constant clothing management challenges. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 7,700 feet and climbing to 10,500 feet at Los Pinos Pass means oxygen-starved racing the entire day. Route guides specifically warn that "higher altitude might pose a challenge for folks coming from out of state, as they'll likely feel the effects of the elevation." Laurel Darren initially "could not even get up the freaking ski hill" when training from scratch at altitude. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: The route follows sections of the Great Divide Mountain Bike Route through wilderness terrain including Lick Park Road and Lost Canyon. From The Ground Up riders describe "pristine gravel roads and exhilarating doubletrack that tested our riders technical skills" with route sections specifically designed to let riders "fail, learn, and adjust." Course creator Joel Grimmett spent "more than two years riding, driving, studying maps and running into lots of dead-ends."

prestige.explanation: A $5,000 prize purse and podium finishes by competitive riders like Sarah show some racing credibility, but the field remains small and regional. Elite rider Nick Gould's participation adds legitimacy, but this five-year-old event hasn't achieved broader recognition beyond Colorado mountain gravel circles.

race_quality.explanation: The course delivers what Nick Gould calls "one of the hardest days" on a bike, with sustained technical challenges and proper mountain suffering. Race creator Joel Grimmett spent two years developing a route with "great amount of unpaved surface variety with as little pavement as possible." Two aid stations and well-planned logistics support the 120-mile mountain challenge.

experience.explanation: From The Ground Up riders finished "by the roaring Gunnison River with Jermaine's sandwiches" and celebrated at "Garlic Mike's overlooking the Gunnison River." The route showcases "more than 1,000 miles of Forest Service roads in Gunnison County that are rideable on a gravel bike." Post-race includes local BBQ and community gathering in downtown Gunnison.

community.explanation: From The Ground Up riders enjoyed local infrastructure including "Jermaine's sandwiches," "Garlic Mike's overlooking the Gunnison River," and "breakfast at the Backcountry Cafe." The event receives grants from the City of Gunnison and profits support Gunnison Trails. Local businesses and trail advocacy create a supportive mountain town atmosphere around the race.

field_depth.explanation: Elite riders like Nick Gould and Laurel Darren participate alongside competitive racers like Sarah who found podium success, but overall depth remains limited by the remote location and altitude demands. plindley's mechanical DNF at 30 miles shows how conditions filter the field, leaving mostly Colorado mountain riders who understand high-altitude gravel challenges. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three. As Official Info puts it: "A portion of the race profit helps support Gunnison Trails"

value.explanation: $80-120 registration delivers 120 miles through Colorado Rockies terrain with a $5,000 prize purse and post-race support. Race profits support Gunnison Trails and the event receives city grants, showing reinvestment in the community. Access to "more than 1,000 miles of Forest Service roads" and local dining spots like Jermaine's sandwiches add value beyond race day.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-$120. Plindley's 4 flats in 30 miles requiring tire inserts and careful equipment choices add gear costs beyond standard gravel setups. Remote Gunnison location means limited lodging options and either expensive regional flights or 3.5-hour mountain drives from Denver. Small town infrastructure keeps some costs reasonable but travel logistics create unavoidable expenses. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: High-altitude gravel that separates your actual fitness from your sea-level delusions.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can sustain power above 8,000 feet and have low gears for Cochetopa Pass, this is honest mountain suffering without the Leadville circus. Sea-level riders thinking they'll adapt on race day will discover what oxygen debt feels like around mile 40. The terrain isn't technical, but the altitude will expose every fitness gap you've been hiding behind at home.
final_verdict.alternatives: Leadville Trail 100 MTB offers similar altitude punishment with more prestige and twice the suffering. SBT GRVL gives you Colorado gravel without the oxygen penalty if you want the scenery but need to breathe.

citations.label: velo.outsideonline.com: The Grind A Not Quite Farewell To Gravel
zenocycleparts.com: Glorious Gravel Grinding In Colorado S Gunnison County

videos.title: Sage and Saddles - The Gunnison Bikepacking Loop
videos.description:
Sage and Saddles is a week-long bikepacking route that travels through the incredibly diverse landscapes of Gunnison County, Colorado. The 220-mile route begins in the vibrant town of Gunnison and forms a spectacular loop by traversing the high sage desert to the south before turning north into the Sawatch mountain range. Our latest video showcases the Sage and Saddles route, and why Gunnison is such a great starting point for your next bikepacking adventure. 

Outline:
Intro - 0:00
Gunnison Bikepacking - 0:42
Sage and Saddles Route - 2:41
Route Logistics - 4:20
Route Highlights - 5:12

Sage and Saddles -  The Gunnison Bikepacking Loop: https://bikepacking.com/routes/sage-and-saddles/

Big thanks to Jonathan and Kristi for their time. 
You can find Kristi and here amazing Silversmith work here: https://tinyurl.com/3tzbdtmx

This video was supported by
Salsa Cycles: https://www.salsacycles.com/bikes/road/journeyer?utm_source=bikepacking.com&utm_medium=youtube&utm_campaign=-123099&utm_id=sal-2064450
Teravail Tire: https://www.teravail.com/product/teravail-sparwood-tire-394764-1.htm?utm_source=bikepacking.com&utm_medium=youtube&utm_campaign=-123099&utm_id=ter-1992250
Surly Bikes: https://surlybikes.com/?utm_source=bikepacking.com&utm_medium=youtube&utm_campaign=-123099&utm_id=sur-2065070


Do you enjoy our videos, routes, and articles? Help sustain this resource by joining the Bikepacking Collective:  https://bikepacking.com/join/?utm_source=youtube

#bikepacking #pedalfurther #sageandsaddles

Neil Beltchenko (https://www.instagram.com/neil_beltchenko/)
Geometry: 150lbs, 5'9.5", 32" inseam

videos.title: Gravel Biking in Pitkin and Tincup, Colorado with Nick Gould
videos.description:
Follow professional gravel biker Nick Gould as he trains for the Gunni Grinder on a route through the picturesque small towns of Tincup and Pitkin, Colorado. These towns are nestled in the heart of Gunnison County’s abundant public lands. Mining and railroad legacies run deep through this corner of Colorado. The rich history of the area around Tincup, Pitkin and Cumberland Pass is equaled by stunning alpine scenery.

More about gravel biking in Gunnison and Crested Butte, Colorado: https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/things-to-do/gravel-biking/ 

The Gunni Grinder: https://www.thegunnigrinder.com/

Start planning your trip at https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/.

Connect with us!

Subscribe to our channel: 
@GunnisonCrestedButte

Follow us on social media:
Facebook: Gunnison Crested Butte - https://www.facebook.com/GCBTA
Instagram: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.instagram.com/gunnisoncrestedbutte/
TikTok: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.tiktok.com/@gunnisoncrestedbutte

Pitkin and Tin Cup

explore around here and the area is
popular with the off-roading crowd not
to mention the incredible views from
Cumberland Pass at over 12 000 feet
that was rad high elevation killer views
and chunky gravel made for an awesome
ride

videos.title: FTGU Season 4: Gravel Training Camp in Gunnison, CO
videos.description: In an effort to prepare our riders for the mountainous, high altitude terrain they will face at SBT GRVL, we brought them out to Gunnison, CO to test their legs, lungs, and skills. Thank you to @GunnisonCrestedButte for having us out in your beautiful, adventurous, and fun town. We will be back! #FTGU

videos.title: Gravel Biking in Crested Butte, Colorado with Nick Gould
videos.description:
Follow professional gravel biker Nick Gould as he trains for the Gunni Grinder. He tours through a scenic, high-elevation zone north of Crested Butte, Colorado. The road over Paradise Divide is steep, challenging and stunningly beautiful, delivering epic views of the Elk Mountains. This is Nick’s last training ride for the Gunni Grinder gravel race in Gunnison in September. 

More about gravel biking in Crested Butte and Gunnison, Colorado: https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/things-to-do/gravel-biking/ 

The Gunni Grinder: https://www.thegunnigrinder.com/

Start planning your trip at https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/.

Connect with us!

Subscribe to our channel: 
@GunnisonCrestedButte

Follow us on social media:
Facebook: Gunnison Crested Butte - https://www.facebook.com/GCBTA
Instagram: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.instagram.com/gunnisoncrestedbutte/
TikTok: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.tiktok.com/@gunnisoncrestedbutte

videos.title: Gravel Biking at Hartman Rocks with Nick Gould
videos.description:
Follow pro gravel biker Nick Gould on a tour through Hartman Rocks Recreation Area as he trains for the Gunni Grinder. Hartman Rocks is a treasure trove of dirt roads and singletrack near Gunnison, Colorado. Granite rock formations and rolling hills of sagebrush cover this high desert landscape. Hartman Rocks is adjacent to many other dirt and paved roads near Gunnison, Saguache, and Pitkin, making it a convenient jumping-off point for day rides or longer bikepacking routes. 

More about gravel biking in Gunnison and Crested Butte, Colorado: https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/things-to-do/gravel-biking/.

Discover Hartman Rocks at https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/places-to-go/parks-and-outdoors/hartman-rocks-recreation-area/.

The Gunni Grinder: https://www.thegunnigrinder.com/ 

Start planning your trip at https://gunnisoncrestedbutte.com/visit/trip-planning/.

Connect with us!

Subscribe to our channel: 
@GunnisonCrestedButte

Follow us on social media:
Facebook: Gunnison Crested Butte - https://www.facebook.com/GCBTA
Instagram: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.instagram.com/gunnisoncrestedbutte/
TikTok: @gunnisoncrestedbutte - https://www.tiktok.com/@gunnisoncrestedbutte

videos.curation_reason: Training ride at Hartman Rocks which appears to be part of the Gunni Grinder course with terrain preview.

quotes.text: High elevation killer views and chunky gravel made for an awesome ride.
This train is a great mix of Road surfaces and should help me prepare for the very terrain of the grinder.

key_challenges.name: Altitude
key_challenges.description: Riders emphasize the significant elevation challenge, with one noting coming from 2500 feet elevation to Gunnison requiring several days to ease into the altitude.

terrain_notes.text: Dust and technical sections are prominent features riders encounter throughout the course.
The route covers very varied terrain in a small distance, starting in sagebrush with sprawling vistas and distant mountains, then progressing into the mountains themselves.
The course offers a great mix of road surfaces that help prepare riders for very varied terrain.

race_day_tips.text: Coming from lower elevations, it's beneficial to have a couple of days to ease into the significant altitude before racing.

additional_quotes.text: 35 percent of all gravel roads in Colorado are in Gunnison County
Gunnison County is 93% public land and we're surrounded by BLM and then forest service
The whole time we were riding there was never a point where there was not an unbelievable view you could just see peaks and hills for miles and tons of wildlife

rider_intel.search_text: The Gunni Grinder takes place in Gunnison County, Colorado, which contains 35 percent of all gravel roads in Colorado and is 93% public land surrounded by BLM and forest service areas. Riders face significant altitude challenges, with the elevation requiring several days of acclimatization for those coming from lower elevations. The course features dust and technical sections throughout, with very varied terrain that progresses from sagebrush areas with sprawling vistas and distant mountains to riding directly in the mountains themselves. The route offers a great mix of road surfaces across this varied terrain. Gunnison County provides 800 miles of single track and millions of acres of public land access, making it an ideal location for challenging gravel racing with dramatic elevation changes and diverse landscape features.
